div.p: The goal of this HIT is to categorize tweets into one of 5 categories - the author of the tweet...
1) Is making a request; 2) Is asking a question; 3) Is reporting a problem; 4) Is angry or unhappy; 5) None of the above.
Here are example tweets of each category:

tr.th: Examples of tweet that belongs in this category

ol.li: dear @awscloud it would be really great to have custom tabs on the aws console with searches on. I have too many instances already :)
@awscloud It would be cool if we received an alert that we are nearing a service limit before we actually hit it.
@awscloud Please send me an AWS t-shirt.
@awscloud Hello. Do you have a dedicated Account Manager handle individual accounts?
Seriously though, @awscloud - how is the request rate limit determined? How do I get it boosted?
@jeremeamia Thanks for the quick response. So when do honorary members of the @awscloud team get AWS t-shirts? :) /cc @jeffbarr
@awsforphp I believe the latest PHP SDK (v2.6.16) is broken again. More details coming. @jeffbarr @awscloud @jeremeamia
@awsforphp @jeffbarr @awscloud @jeremeamia PHP SDK v2.6.15 works fine. Error happens on @AWSOpsWorks PHP v5.3.29 with PHP SDK 2.6.16
It's insulting that @awscloud marked an EBS volume limit increase support request as low severity but I can't do anything while I wait.
All I have ever heard about @awscloud Amazon customer service is rave reviews, but I'm sure having a hell of a time with \"Santhosh.\" #pissed
Tweets that don't belong to any of the above categories; should land in here.

div.em: The underlying purpose of this HIT is to identify the tweets which need attention from a customer service representative who can address the concerns of the author of the tweet.
